multiagent-system.name: Multiagent system
multiagent-system.definition: is a collection of multiple autonomous agents, each acting towards its objectives while all interacting in a shared environment, being able to communicate and possibly coordinate their actions.

agent.name: Agent
agent.definition:
[Russell & Norvig] An agent is anything that can perceive its environment (through its sensors) and act upon that environment (through its effectors).
[Wooldridge & Jennings] An agent is a computer system that is situated in some environment, and that is capable of autonomous action in this environment in order to meet its design objectives/delegated goals.

autonomous.name: autonomous
autonomous.definition: the agent is self goal-directed and acts without requiring user initiation and guidance; it can choose its own goal and the way to achieve it; its behavior is determined by its experience; we have no direct control over it

reactive.name: reactive
reactive.definition: the agent maintains an ongoing interaction with its environment, and responds to changes that occur in it

proactive.name: proactive
proactive.definition: the agent generates and attempts to achieve goals; it is not driven solely by events but takes the initiative

sociable.name: sociable
sociable.definition: the agent interacts with other agents (and possibly humans) via cooperation, coordination, and negotiation; it is aware and able to reason about other agents and how they can help it achieve its own goals

coordination.name: coordination
coordination.definition: is managing the interdependencies between actions of multiple agents (not necessarily cooperative)

cooperation.name: cooperation
cooperation.definition: is working together as a team to achieve a shared goal

negotiation.name: negotiation
negotiation.definition: is the ability to reach agreements on matters of common interest

agent-function.name: Agent function
agent-function.definition: Agent’s behavior is described by the agent function that maps percept sequences to actions.

agent-program.name: Agent program
agent-program.definition: runs on a physical architecture to produce agent function.

rational-agent.name: Rational agent
rational-agent.definition: chooses whichever action maximizes the expected value of the performance measure given the percept sequence to date and whatever bulit-in knowledge the agent has.

fully-observable-vs-partially-observable.name: Fully observable vs. partially observable
fully-observable-vs-partially-observable.definition: can agents obtain complete and correct information about the state of the world?

deterministic-vs-stochastic.name: Deterministic vs. stochastic
deterministic-vs-stochastic.definition: Do actions have guaranteed and uniquely defined effects?

episodic-vs-sequential.name: Episodic vs. sequential
episodic-vs-sequential.definition: Can agents decisions be made for different, independent episodes?

static-vs-dynamic.name: Static vs. dynamic
static-vs-dynamic.definition: Does the environment change by processes beyond agent control?

discrete-vs-continuous.name: Discrete vs. continuous
discrete-vs-continuous.definition: Is the number of actions and percepts fixed and finite?

single-agent-vs-multi-agent.name: Single-agent vs. multi-agent
single-agent-vs-multi-agent.definition: Does the behavior of one agent depends on the behavior of other agents?

simple-reflex-agents.name: Simple Reflex Agents
simple-reflex-agents.definition: chooses the next action on the basis of the current percept only.

model-based-reflex-agent.name: Model-based Reflex Agent
model-based-reflex-agent.definition: Keeps track of the world by extracting relevant information from percepts and storing it in its memory.

goal-based-agents.name: Goal-based Agents
goal-based-agents.definition: Goal-based agents are more flexible, they use search and planning.

utility-based-agents.name: Utility-based Agents
utility-based-agents.definition: use the utility function to choose the most desirable action/course of actions to take.

utility.name: Utility
utility.definition: is a function that maps a state onto a real number; it captures “quality” of a state. If an agent prefers one world state to another state then the former state has higher utility for the agent.

intelligent-agent.name: Intelligent agent
intelligent-agent.definition: is autonomous, proactive, reactive and sociable.

auction.name: Auction
auction.definition:
mechanism for allocating resource among self-interested agents
[Shoham & Leyton-Brown 2009] An auction is a protocol that allows agents (=bidders) to indicate their interests in one or more resources and that uses these indications of interest to determine both an allocation of resources and a set of payments by the agents.

bidding-rules.name: Bidding rules
bidding-rules.definition: How offers are made: by whom, when, what their content is

clearing-rules.name: Clearing rules
clearing-rules.definition: Who gets which goods (allocation) and what money changes hands (payment).

information-rules.name: Information rules
information-rules.definition: What information about the state of the negotiation is revealed to whom and when.

common-value.name: Common value
common-value.definition: the good has the same value to all agents example: a 100 dollar note

private-value.name: Private value
private-value.definition: an agent A’s valuation of the good is independent from other agent’s valuation of the good example: a painting, John Lennon’s last dollar bill

correlated-value.name: Correlated value
correlated-value.definition: valuations of the good are related, i.e. the more other agents are prepared to pay, the more agent A prepared to pay. example: purchase of items for later resale

agent-s-payoff-from-participating-in-an-.name: Agent’s payoff from participating in an auction
agent-s-payoff-from-participating-in-an-.definition: if winner: payoff = item’s valuation – price paid for the item; if not winner: payoff = zero

multi-unit-auctions.name: Multi-Unit Auctions
multi-unit-auctions.definition: multiple units of the same item are available for auction

multi-item-auctions.name: Multi-Item Auctions
multi-item-auctions.definition: bidding for multiple items grouped together

reverse-auctions.name: Reverse Auctions
reverse-auctions.definition: The buyer issues a request for bids to his providers.

multi-attribute-auctions.name: Multi-Attribute Auctions
multi-attribute-auctions.definition: Negotiation over further attributes beyond price, e.g. color, weight, or delivery time

english-auction.name: English Auction
english-auction.definition: Auctioneer starts the bidding at some reservation price. Bidders then shout out ascending prices (minimum increments). Once bidders stop shouting, the high bidder gets the good at that price.

japanese-auction.name: Japanese Auction
japanese-auction.definition:
Same as an English auction except that the auctioneer calls out the prices
All bidders start out standing. When the price reaches a level that a bidder is not willing to pay, that bidder sits down. Once a bidder sits down, they can't get back up the last person standing gets the good.

dutch-auction.name: Dutch Auction
dutch-auction.definition: The auctioneer starts ahigh value; it descends clock at some. At some point, a bidder shouts “mine!" and gets the good at the price shown on the clock. Good when items need to be sold quickly (similar to Japanese auction) No information is given away during auction.

first-price-sealed-bid-auction.name: First-price sealed bid auction
first-price-sealed-bid-auction.definition: Bidders write down bids on pieces of paper. Suctioneer awards the good to the bidder with the highest bid. That bidder pays the amount of his bid.

second-price-sealed-bid-auction.name: Second-price sealed bid auction
second-price-sealed-bid-auction.definition: Same as First-price sealed bid auction except winner pays the amount bid by the second-highest bidder alias: Vickerey auction
